roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now on number oh one four hundred, Ricky Bell versus Gary Bradford Cone.
Mr. M- Mr. Moore.

Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court The court of appeals was without authority to grant habeas relief under twenty-eight USC twenty-two fifty-four D one on respondent's ineffective assistance of counsel claim for two reasons: first, because the State court decision rejecting the claim correctly identified this Court's decision in Strickland versus Washington as the clearly established Federal law governing this case, not United States versus Cronic as respondent contends, and second, because the State court's application of Strickland to the facts of respondent's case was not objectively unreasonable.

Turning to the first point, respondent's ineffective assistance claim from the outset of this case has asserted two specific errors that his attorney allegedly committed during the sentencing phase of his capital trial first, counsel's alleged failure to present available mitigating evidence and second, his counsel's decision to waive closing argument.
This Court held in Strickland that such claims are properly analyzed under the two part actual deficient performance slash actual prejudice test announced in that case itself.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Moore, I think what happened in this sentencing proceeding, if I remember correctly, is that the attorney made some remarks at the beginning of the sentencing hearing?
Yes, Your Honor.

He delivered an opening statement, during which he specifically called the jury's attention, as he is permitted to do under Tennessee State law, to guilt phase evidence, mental health evidence, upon which he was relying in mitigation.
He explained to the jury its mitigating significance by relating that evidence specifically to three statutory mitigating factors.
In addition, during that opening statement, he emphasized his client's remorse for his role in the crimes.
He emphasized his client's honorable service for his...
country.
Did he...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: explain that he wouldn't be presenting any evidence or saying anything more?
He He did not indicate one way or the other in that statement,
but he specifically...
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, would you be here would you still be here if he had not said anything at the opening? Then what rule applies? Suppose the defense attorney just totally remained silent in the sentencing phase.
No, Your Honor.
It is our...

It is our position that if the claim focuses on counsel's conduct during the trial and it is not alleged that any errors or omissions he made were the result of State interru- interference or so called surrounding circumstances, then such a claim is properly analyzed under Strickland's two part test.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the err- the attorney here did successfully object to the presentation of some evidence during the sentencing phase,
didn't he?
indeed, Your Honor, he did.
In addition,
he he objected to some hearsay evidence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: J- just to go back to Justice O'Connor's question, suppose the attorney says nothing and la- later says, y- you know, I was just I don't know stressed out, traumatized.
No, Your Honor.
N- No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: When does Cronic apply?
Cronic in our view is properly read to apply only when surrounding circumstances or State interference renders it unlikely that any lawyer could have re- rendered effective assistance of counsel.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, in my hy- in my hypothetical, I said he he said I just blanked out for a minute.
But th- that circumstance is the the lawyer's own problem.
ascertain whether that error preju-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: given in this case that the attorney did provide that there was ineffective assistance at sentencing? Do we take that as a a gi-
No your honor No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This is not the first time in one of these cases I've been surprised at how skimpy the presentation is at by the defense counsel on sentencing.
Well, Your Hon-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: tempted to ask you if i- if this is usual, but th- th- that that's probably not a fair question is it there're so many differences in so many cases.
That's correct, Your Honor.
counsel when...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Moore, may I ask you? On that on that branch of it, it seems to me that there was, the prosecutor's presentation to the jury was about a match for the defense attorney's.
Y- Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But I had another question that I wanted to ask you, and that was you presented two questions.
Yes, Your...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As a matter and and the Sixth Circuit proceeded just the other way.

Well, it's our it's our position, Your Honor, that it is not the function of this Court under twenty-two fifty-four D to reach to actually address the merits a- as if it were deciding this claim de novo.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Don't you think it'd be a little coy for us to decide, well, it wasn't an unreasonable application of of Federal law when we, in fact, know or believe that it was a correct application of Federal law? Do you insist that we simply say and go no further than to say, oh, it was it was not an unreasonable er application?
I I certainly would not b- begrudge the Court's agreeing that the State court had indeed correctly applied Strickland.
ascertaining...
whether it is reasonable.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Indeed, if we could go no further than than the coy statement that it was not an unreasonable application, I suppose you shouldn't've had two questions.
That's correct, Your Honor.
argument...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: le- let me interrupt you.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

And so, i- i- in- indeed, counsel could've reasonably believed that all of the points he had made during his opening statement, his plea for mercy, his emphasis on his client's remorse, and the mitigating significance of the guilt phase evidence, were fresh in the jury's mind when the jury retired to deliberate because...
that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: what did he say about the Bronze Star?

During his opening statement, he did not specifically mention the Bronze Star because that evidence was not elicited until the his cross examination of one of the witnesses during the sentencing phase.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, your answer is he didn't mention it in his argument.
He did not mention the Bronze Star.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But am I right that such evidence was introduced in the Federal court?
No, Your Honor.
none of that evidence...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that such evidence was available made in the Federal proceeding?
The allegation that it was available was made in the Federal proceeding, but there was no...
And was that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: allegation denied?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah.
Well, I don't know that it was denied.
on...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but if we're not deciding the case on the basis of what that evidence would prove or disprove, but rather on whether counsel was deficient in failing to introduce it, should we not assume the evidence exists?
No, Your Honor.
We should not?
No, Your Honor.
If If...
b- b- because the burden rests with the petitioner, the habeas petitioner, to demonstrate its existence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What what was the bas- what was the case you just cited to us for that proposition?
Burger versus Kemp.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Moore, er are you done with that point? I...
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I- It isn't stated in your brief, but I assume that it's it's it's the Tennessee rule that if if the defense doesn't make a closing a closing statement, the prosecution doesn't either.
That's right, and that was the...
s- s-
the State court found, based on the...
evidence...
presented to it during the post conviction hearing that counsel made a tactical decision to waive in in order to prevent the senior prosecutor from delivering what he...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The fearsome Mr. Strother.
I am not I am not acquainted with General Strother, so I'm not...
sure, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: gather that this isn't the only occasion on which defense counsel have esch- eschewed the making of closing argument for fear that Mr. Strother would be enabled to unleash his his weaponry.
That's correct, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Can we go back to the Bronze Star? It certainly did come out in the sentencing phase.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do we have any evidence to indicate whether Mr. Dice would have put on evidence showing the Bronze Star if he had not been able to bring it out in cross examination?
The record simply doesn't reflect whether or not that would've been the case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you think he was entitled to be pleased with himself for the way he got that in the record?
Your Honor, I th-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That is that the way you would have done it if you'd been the lawyer?
I'm not certain that I that th- hearsay evidence in a prison record is the best evidence of that fact.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that's all the jury found out about it, too.
That's correct, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: th- And we know nothing more about it now? Nothing came out in the Tennessee proceedings...
No, Your Honor,
and r- and and r-
respondent introduced no evidence before the State courts concerning why th- the the Bronze Star was awarded, anything about the circumstances of its award.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was it were there any problems in his service record? He served in Germany and Vietnam.
Not so insofar as this record reflects, Your Honor, no.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And did the lawyer put in any evidence about his what kind of a person he was before he went to Vietnam?
During sentencing? No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Moore.
Blatt, we'll hear from you.

[NS] Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court The United States has addressed the second question presented, which is whether a defendant must show prejudice to establish a claim of ineffective assistance.
[Inaudible]
to assume then that the performance was deficient and then address the prejudice prong? No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: don't get to question two at all, then.

You get to you can ge- you get to question two if, in determining that Strickland and not Cronic is the clearly established law, this Court holds that Cronic does not apply when the claim is an actual ineffective assistance claim.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What what if the defense counsel presented nothing at all at the sentencing phase, do you think that there is potential for application of Cronic in those circumstances?
Yes, Justice O'Connor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: in that re-
We do but our difference is very narrow.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why divide trial into, you know, the one phase and then the the mitigation phase? It's all part of the same trial.
and say...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: counsel utterly failed to to litigate this particular piece.
Okay, and We couldn't agree with you more.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what justification do you have for for separating out the mitigation phase from the other, especially when some of the evidence that went to mitigation was presented during during the direct phase?
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you're giving up the principle.
We don't think...
so, what...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: it just be th- th- here's a counsel who litigated the case properly but he made he made a mistake in in in his litigation? He didn't put on any evidence in the in the mitigation phase.
We don't think so.
be the result of any...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: when you say the entire trial, are you talking about the penalty phase or the whole ca- the whole trial?

We would be talking about a penalty phase although I agree with Justice Scalia that in the unique situation of this case, where there's an express procedure that allows the jury to consider the mitigation evidence, it's critical to look at counsel's performance during the g- the guilt phase of the trial.
Counsel...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: me.
the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: penalty phase?
No, I don't think that is unique and I I'm sorry I...
I misspoke. I think it's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Which means the two phases are linked.

Right, and if you d- if we're just talking if you take it out of the capital proceeding so you don't have the split trial, all we're saying is if there's an entire failure, we would think that it would be appropriate to presume prejudice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why isn't the line is it know, that you can draw a line one place doesn't mean it's sensible to draw it every place.
That's correct.
So,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: w- one can say yes I see these are two parts it doesn't follow from that that I have to then separate every examination and every cross examination It's a question of where you draw the line.
Well, I think that's correct, and however you draw the line, this case falls on the Strickland side of the line because this is not a case where counsel didn't do anything.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I ask? Supposing you had a case and I know this is not quite it in which there is strong evidence that counsel was mentally disabled and that that made him less effective throughout the entire sentencing hearing.
It would be under Strickland.
Even if...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: there was severe mental illness on the part of counsel?
Is counsel's j- things that would go to impair counsel judgments or generally irrelevant unless they manifest themself manifest themselves in objectively unreasonable conduct.
because...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: treat the failure to make a closing statement or the failure to put in any evidence whatsoever e- e- exactly as if he were a fully qualified lawyer in such a case.
That's right.
presumption of prejudice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Burger versus Kemp if the district court in this case had wanted to inquire about the availability of other evidence, it was precluded from doing so because it hadn't been introduced in the State collateral proceedings?
ye- The district court ruled that that that those claims were procedurally barred under an adequate and independent State procedure.
proceedings...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: procedural bar rule if the evidence is not adduced at the State collateral proceeding, as opposed to Federal deference?
It was a procedural...
In this context, the claims were not made until subsequent post conviction State court proceedings.
barred.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: was just the failure to adduce the to to make the claim rather than to elicit the evidence?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Ms. Blatt.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court The main problem in this case is not specific attorney errors.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, he did say something initially, did he not, at the sentencing phase?
Justice O'Connor, he did but I would like to clear up one thing that Mr. Moore stated.
One...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well I just I hope you will address that because if he actually did something but it was somehow inadequate assistance, then perhaps Strickland is the test.
But if...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: he did absolutely nothing, then we have to wrestle with whether you divide it from, you know, sentencing phase from guilt innocence phase, and so forth.

Justice O'Connor, Mr. Dice did make an opening statement, but in that opening statement, he also told the jury that he had a right to put on evidence at the penalty phase and had a right to make a closing argument in the penalty phase.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it's really bad performance, you can argue, having especially having made that statement, not to do it.
But But...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I don't think that it proves that he wasn't there.

Justice Scalia, the problem in this case and the reason there's a total abdication of advocacy is because after the ca- State made a case for death, after the State put on proof of aggravating circumstances and then argued to the jury that the law required the jury to put Mr. Cone to death, there was silence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, he had he had asked questions on cross examination, and it may be that he was satisfied that the State hadn't shown much.
He wasn't...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: going to give them an opportunity to have some stem winder and and and this is not standard but it is is it is not an unknown strategy.
It was a...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: very effective strategy for that particular advocate.
Justice Kennedy, the only role of an advocate in the penalty phase of a capital trial is to make a case for life.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Or it implies to the jury that the State has shown nothing.
That's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: a completely permissible inference, and counsel does that has been known to do that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: W- We have counsel up here sometimes who say I I waive rebuttal.
Justice Scalia, if a member of the Court asked a question of counsel and counsel stood silent, the necessary implication of that is I have no good reply for that question.
Mr.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Hutton, this was a very short proceeding.
Yes,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It shows that Mr. Dice did did something.
Well, Your Honor, I would submit we know that Mr. Dice was suffering from mental illness at the time he testified.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm asking you about those words.

Y- Your Honor, I think e- I would submit that that's more of a statement of grandiosity, but even if it was a plea for mercy, our position is that after the opening statements, nothing happened to make a case for life.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: W- Why W- Th- I'd like you to go into that.
exactly the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: same reaction as Justice Ginsburg.
Justice Breyer, there there're two points in response.
In other words,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you're saying on that part...
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: when Paul Freund sometimes has said, a lawyer in this Court who sits down saying nothing makes not just a good argument, but a perfect argument.
Okay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: My reading this transcript led me to think maybe it wasn't the perfect response, but it was a good one, because in the introductory statement I'll repeat myself he made all his arguments.
Number one, Your Honor, it's not just the failure to make a statement.
conviction...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: me.
No, Your Honor.
penalty phase.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: allude to that evidence?
No, Your Honor.
mitigating ev-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but surely the jury would assume that they could consider it if he referred to it.
Your Honor, for a jury who's just rejected an insanity defense and this will Justice Scalia, this plays into the second point, too.
pro-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He says the defense has put on proof of those mitigating circumstances during its case.

Justice Breyer, ther- the problem with that evidence was that the post conviction court made a finding there was prosecutorial misconduct where the prosecution improperly argued that the jury should not believe the evidence with respect to drug usage.
phase.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you go to I don't want you to lose two, though.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Because I want to elicit from you what your response is.
Okay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well I, you know, I have trouble with that because I don't think the State put on very much, and if I'm sitting waiting for this closing argument, I know what I'm going to hear.
Hm.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But then the prosecutor says, this man with a Bronze Star killed a helpless, innocent couple.
got me...
But Justice Kennedy, at least then the jury has something to weigh.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right.
No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.
Justice Breyer, put another way, the question the Court is asking is whether or not a lawyer can strategically decide to abandon advocacy.

your client?

and...
